thread.title_full: MTA's $21.7 billion debt just got a credit-rating upgrade from Moody's

author: Bloomberg News
title: MTA's $21.7 billion debt just got a credit-rating upgrade from Moody's
text:
Photo: Newscom Moody's rating reflects MTA's soon-to-be-funded $32 billion five-year capital plan. 
New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority had its credit rating raised by Moody's Investors Service because of the strengthening finances of the city and state and ridership at the highest since the 1940s. 
The largest U.S. transportation agency's rating on $21.7 billion of debt was raised one step to A1, Moody's fifth-highest investment grade, even as the operator of New York City's subways, buses and commuter rail lines faces a $15 billion deficit in its five-year capital plan. 
"The upgrade to the A1 rating primarily reflects trends of improvement over recent years in the MTA's operating environment, including strong service area economic growth and strengthened financial condition of supporting governments," Moody's said in a statement. 
New York City's revenue exceeded forecasts in the year that ended last month, driven by a windfall from taxes on property, residents' incomes and retail sales. The state's finances have also been buoyed by more than $7 billion in legal settlements from financial firms, which left the state with a surplus after passing its fifth consecutive on-time budget in April. 
Subway ridership in New York City reached its highest in more than 65 years in April, according to the MTA. Last year, some 5.6 million customers rode the subway on an average weekday, the most since 1949. 
Moody's said its rating reflects the MTA's yet-to-be fully funded $32 billion five-year capital plan and its "high" costs for debt and employee retirement benefits.
